## Władysław Reymont's Railway Experience and Lipce Village

Władysław Reymont worked as a gateman at a railway crossing near Koluszki for 16 rubles a month, thanks to his father's connections after returning to Tuszyn. His experiences from this period led to correspondence pieces from Rogów, Koluszki and Skierniewice that were accepted for publication by Głos (The Voice) in Warsaw in 1892.

## Connection to "The Peasants" Novel

Reymont set the action of "The Peasants" in Lipce, a real village which he came to know during his work on the railway near Skierniewice. Reymont also stayed for a time in Krosnowa near Lipce, which gave him intimate knowledge of the area.

## Real Location of Lipce

Lipce Reymontowskie (until 1983 called simply Lipce) is a village in Skierniewice County, Łódź Voivodeship, in central Poland. It lies approximately 16 kilometres (10 mi) south-west of Skierniewice and 36 km (22 mi) east of the regional capital Łódź. Polish novelist Władysław Stanisław Reymont placed the plot of his novel The Peasants in the village of Lipce.

## The Novel's Authenticity

The village's renaming to "Lipce Reymontowskie" (Reymont's Lipce) in 1983 honors the writer's connection to the location. The Peasants is set exclusively in the village of Lipce in central Poland, and Reymont's firsthand experience working on the railway in the area provided him with detailed knowledge of rural life that informed his Nobel Prize-winning novel.

This connection between Reymont's practical work experience as a railway gateman and his literary masterpiece demonstrates how his real-world observations in the Skierniewice region directly influenced one of Polish literature's most celebrated works.
